## Course Description

Estimation theory; hypothesis tests; confidence intervals; goodness-of-fit tests; correlation and linear regression; analysis of variance; non-parametric methods

<details>
<summary><strong>Objectives</strong></summary>

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

- Summarize and visualize data appropriately.
- Use probability models to reason about randomness.
- Construct and interpret confidence intervals.
- Perform and interpret hypothesis tests.
- Fit and interpret simple regression models.
- Use Python to support statistical computation and reproducible analysis.

</details>

## Course Outline

<details>
<summary><strong>Introduction</strong></summary>

- What is statistical inference?  
- Review of probability
  - Random variables and their distributions
  - Populations and samples
  - Sample statistics

</details>


<details>
<summary><strong>Estimates of Population Parameters</strong></summary>

- Bias of estimates
- Confidence intervals
- Relative efficiency, consistency and sufficiency
- Minimum variance unbiased estimation
- Moment Estimators
- Maximum Likelihood Estimates

</details>

<details>
<summary><strong>Hypothesis Testing</strong></summary>

- Common tests for means and variances
- Relationship between hypothesis tests and confidence intervals
- Power of tests
- Likelihood ratio tests
- Comparison of more than two means
- Analysis of categorical data

</details>

<details>
<summary><strong>Linear Models and Least Squares</strong></summary>

- Linear Model
- Method of Least Squares
- Inferences concerning regression coefficients
- Hypothesis testing and model selection
- Correlation

</details>


<details>
<summary><strong>Nonparametric Statistics</strong></summary>

- Matched pairs of experiments
- Comparison of two populations
- Comparison of more than two populations

</details>
